isis.stitle: FULL POWER HYDRAULIC ABS BRAKE SYSTEM - SYSTEM MAINTENANCE - PRESSURE BLEEDING THE FULL POWER BRAKE SYSTEM

svcproc.title: PRESSURE BLEEDING THE FULL POWER BRAKE SYSTEM

important.para: During bleeding procedures, brake fluid level must not be allowed to fall below the MIN mark on the Master Cylinder (MC) reservoir. The MC reservoir should be regularly checked and filled to the MAX mark with new DOT 3 or DOT 4 brake fluid. Failure to keep the brake reservoir level above the MIN mark could result in more air entering the system, making it impossible to effectively bleed the system.

Do not add fluid above the MAX mark. When the system is depressurized during service, fluid stored in the accumulators is returned to the MC reservoir. If the reservoir is filled above the MAX mark a fluid spill could occur when these conditions exists.

Each bleeding procedure may be performed as a standalone procedure or in conjunction with installation or other bleeding procedures. In this section, the bleeding procedures are provided as standalone procedures including all of the necessary preparation steps. When a bleed procedure is referenced from another procedure, it is not necessary to repeat preparation steps that are duplicated.

svcprocinfo.para: Pressure bleeding is REQUIRED to properly bleed the Full Power Brake system. It requires the use of a pressure bleeder kit, a regulated, clean pressure source with gauge, tubing and adapter. Pressure bleeder kits are available from a number of manufacturers and include instructions for use. Do not attempt to use a vacuum bleeder on this system.

item.para: One clean graduated glass or plastic bottle/receptacle. #
One rubber/plastic bleed hose (preferably transparent). #
Suitable crow's foot adapters for torque wrench (bleeder screws and brake lines).
Pressurized fill and bleed equipment. Either of the following three types may be used:
Fluid over fluid. Provides brake fluid (under pressure) from an external tank to the Master Cylinder (MC) reservoir. Regulated shop air may be used as the pressure source.
Air over fluid. Pressurizes the master cylinder reservoir with clean, dry, regulated shop air. Air regulator/filter ZTSE4757-1, or equivalent, is required.
Air over fluid. Pressurizes the master cylinder reservoir with regulated dry nitrogen.
One MC reservoir cap adapter (International Service Tool - ZTSE4678).
A sufficient supply of new DOT 3 or DOT 4 brake fluid from a sealed container.

svcprocinfo.para: # (must be impervious to the effects of brake fluid).

svcsubproc.title: Master Cylinder (MC) Circuit Bleeding Procedure

important.para: If the parking brake (SAHR) circuit is to be bled as part of this service, the parking brake cable must be disconnected. If the SAHR canister is operable, this should be done before depressurizing the brake system. Refer to SAHR POWERED PARKING BRAKE CIRCUIT BLEEDING PROCEDURE for instructions on disconnecting the cable. After the cable is disconnected, return to this point and complete all other bleeding procedures before performing the parking brake bleed procedure.

step1.para: Install wheel chocks.
Set the ignition key to OFF and remove the two 30 Amp fuses that provide power to the brake system motors. They are in the fuse panel located on the engine side of the cowl (refer to FIGURE 37).

figure.caption: Figure 37. Location of Motor Fuses In Engine Compartment

step1.para: Connect the EZ-TECH ® to the diagnostic connector located under the center of the instrument panel. Refer to FIGURE 38. Set the ignition key to ON, start the EZ-TECH ® and open the TOOLBOX™ program.
Verify that the brake fluid level in the MC reservoir is at the MAX mark.
Depressurize the system as follows:

step2.para: Depress the brake pedal a minimum of 30 times.
Use the EZ-TECH ® and TOOLBOX™ to verify that pressure at both accumulators is at 0 psi.

warning.para: Batteries expel explosive gases. Keep sparks, flames, burning cigarettes, or other ignition sources away at all times. Always wear safety glasses and a face shield when working near batteries to prevent personal injury.

step1.para: Set the ignition key to OFF and disconnect the battery negative cable (including the ECM ground cable).
Prepare the pressure bleeder according to the instructions provided with the equipment.

item.para: If a fluid bleeder system is used, fill the pressure bleeder with new specified brake fluid from a sealed container.

If an air bleeder system is used, the fluid level in the MC reservoir must be monitored to ensure that the level never drops below the MIN mark during the bleed procedure. A typical air-over-fluid bleeder setup using service tools ZTSE4757-1 and ZTSE4678 is shown in FIGURE 39.

step1.para: Install the service tool adapter (ZTSE4678) between the bleed equipment and the MC reservoir filler neck. Ensure that the adapter is securely tightened onto the MC reservoir filler neck.
Apply 2.4 bar (35 PSI) pressure on the MC reservoir with the bleeding equipment.
Fit bleeder hose onto one relay valve bleeder screw located on the HCU. Refer to FIGURE 40. (NOTE: Both MC circuits can be bled at the same time by connecting two bleeder bottles.)
Submerge free end of bleeder hose into the bleed bottle. (Note the fluid level in the bottle before starting.)

Open the 7 mm bleeder screw until the fluid begins to flow (about 3/4 turn). After draining 250 cc (8.5 oz) of fluid, check the stream for air bubbles. When no further air bubbles enter the bleed bottle, close the bleeder screw.
Remove the bleeder hose and torque the bleeder screw to 4 to 4.5 Nm (35.4 to 39.8 Lbf-in).
If only one MC circuit was bled, repeat the previous four steps with the second bleeder screw.
If the wheel calipers are to be bled, refer to the BRAKE CALIPER CIRCUIT BLEEDING PROCEDURE .
If the SAHR canister circuit is to be bled, refer to the SAHR CANISTER CIRCUIT BLEEDING PROCEDURE .
If no further bleeding procedures are to be performed, connect the battery and install the two pump motor fuses.
Switch ON the ignition. HCU pump motors will start up automatically and fill the accumulators (running time approximately 45 seconds).*
Release pressure from the MC reservoir via the bleed equipment. Disconnect bleed equipment from MC reservoir filler neck and install the MC reservoir cap.
Fill (or drain) the MC reservoir to the MAX mark. Use new DOT 3 or DOT 4 brake fluid from a sealed container if filling.
Verify that the MC reservoir cap is installed.
If you were referred to this procedure from an installation procedure, return to the original procedure now; otherwise, proceed to the next step.

Using the EZ-TECH ® and the TOOLBOX™ program clear all brake system related inactive fault codes. (Codes may have been set while disconnecting and reconnecting power to the system.) If active fault codes are indicated, refer to Section 5, DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING
to make the necessary repairs.
Set the ignition key to OFF and disconnect the EZ-TECH ® from the diagnostic connector.
Remove wheel chocks.

svcsubproc.para: * If HCU pump motors fail to deliver a sufficient amount of fluid, the ECU-Module will control the HCU pump motors in a self priming procedure. HCU pump motors should stop within 3 minutes, with brake warning light and buzzer OFF. If that is not the case (one or both pumps do not prime), refer to Section 5, DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING to make the necessary repairs.

svcsubproc.title: Brake Caliper Circuit Bleeding Procedure

step1.para: Install wheel chocks.
Set the ignition key to OFF and remove the two 30 Amp fuses that provide power to the brake system motors. They are in the fuse panel located on the engine side of the cowl. Refer to FIGURE 37 .
Connect the EZ-TECH ® to the diagnostic connector located under the center of the instrument panel. Refer to FIGURE 38 . Set the ignition key to ON, start the EZ-TECH ® and open the TOOLBOX™ program.
Verify that the brake fluid level in the MC reservoir is at the MAX mark.
Depressurize the system as follows:

step2.para: Depress the brake pedal a minimum of 30 times.
Use the EZ-TECH ® and TOOLBOX™ to verify that pressure at both accumulators is at 0 psi.

warning.para: Batteries expel explosive gases. Keep sparks, flames, burning cigarettes, or other ignition sources away at all times. Always wear safety glasses and a face shield when working near batteries to prevent personal injury.

step1.para: Set the ignition key to OFF and disconnect the battery negative cable (including the ECM ground cable).
Prepare the pressure bleeder according to the instructions provided with the equipment.

item.para: If a fluid bleeder system is used, fill the pressure bleeder with new specified brake fluid from a sealed container.

If an air bleeder system is used, the fluid level in the MC reservoir must be monitored to ensure that the level never drops below the MIN mark during the bleed procedure. A typical air-over-fluid bleeder setup is shown in FIGURE 39.

step1.para: Install the service tool adapter (ZTSE4678) between the bleed equipment and the MC reservoir filler neck. Ensure that the adapter is securely tightened onto the MC reservoir filler neck.
Apply 2.4 bar (35 PSI) pressure on the MC reservoir with the bleeding equipment.

note.para: If all wheel ends are being bled, they should be bled in the following order: right rear, left rear, right front, left front.

step1.para: Fit bleeder hose onto the caliper bleeder screw at the first wheel end.
Submerge free end of bleeder hose into the bleed bottle. (Note the fluid level in the bottle before starting.)

Open the bleeder screw until the fluid begins to flow (about 3/4 turn). Refer to FIGURE 41. After draining 250 cc (8.5 oz) of fluid, check the stream for air bubbles. When no further air bubbles enter the bleed bottle, close the bleeder screw.
Remove the bleeder hose and torque the bleeder screw to 12 to 16 Nm (8.6 to 11.5 Lbf-ft).
Repeat steps 10 through 13 for the other calipers being bled.
If other bleeding procedures are to be performed, proceed to those procedures at this time. If no further bleeding procedures are to be performed, proceed to the next step.
Connect the battery and install the two pump motor fuses.
Switch ON the ignition. HCU pump motors will start up automatically and fill the accumulators (running time approximately 45 seconds).*

Using the EZ-TECH ® and the TOOLBOX™ program, select the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function from the EOL pull down menu. This function helps clear air from the system by depressurizing and repressurizing both accumulators. A dialog box will indicate when the function is complete.
Release pressure from the MC reservoir via the bleed equipment. Disconnect bleed equipment from MC reservoir filler neck and install the MC reservoir cap.
Run the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function again by selecting DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS from the EOL pull down menu.
When the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function has completed, fill (or drain) the MC reservoir to the MAX mark. Use new DOT 3 or DOT 4 brake fluid from a sealed container if filling.
Verify that the MC reservoir cap is installed.
If you were referred to this procedure from an installation procedure, return to the original procedure now; otherwise, proceed to the next step.

Using the EZ-TECH ® and the TOOLBOX™ program, clear all brake system related inactive fault codes. (Codes may have been set while disconnecting and reconnecting power to the system.) If active fault codes are indicated, refer to Section 5, DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING
to make the necessary repairs.
Set the ignition key to OFF and disconnect the EZ-TECH ® from the diagnostic connector.
Remove wheel chocks.

svcsubproc.para: * If HCU pump motors fail to deliver a sufficient amount of fluid, the ECU-Module will control the HCU pump motors in a self priming procedure. HCU pump motors should stop within 3 minutes, with brake warning light and buzzer OFF. If that is not the case (one or both pumps do not prime), performing the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function in the following steps should correct the problem. After completing the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function, both accumulators should be fully charged as indicated on the TOOLBOX™ screen. If an accumulator is still not charging correctly refer to Section 5, DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING to make the necessary repairs.

svcsubproc.title: SAHR Parking Brake Circuit Bleeding Procedure
svcsubproc.para: Before bleeding the SAHR circuit, the parking brake cable must be disconnected from the SAHR canister. This ensures that the SAHR piston achieves the full stroke and forces most of the fluid volume out of the SAHR canister, thus moving any trapped air into the bleeder screw area.

caution.para: While removing a parking brake cable, only the threaded rod should rotate. If the cable is to be reused, do not allow the cable to twist during removal.

step1.para: Disconnect the parking brake cable. Refer to FIGURE 42.

item.para: If the parking brake system is inoperable, disconnect the cable as follows:
Install wheel chocks, place the transmission in P, PB or N, and turn the key to OFF.
While using a 15 mm wrench to hold the SAHR canister shaft, loosen the jam nut on the threaded rod with a 16 mm wrench.

While using the 15 mm wrench to hold the canister shaft, unscrew the threaded rod using an 8 mm wrench. The rod must be unscrewed approximately 2.5 inches before the cable disconnects. The cable will exhibit some resistance while being unscrewed because it is under tension.
If the parking brake system is operable, disconnect the cable as follows:
Install wheel chocks, place the transmission in neutral (N), not Park (P and PB), and turn the key ON.
While pressing the brake pedal, press the dash mounted PARK BRAKE switch to release the parking brake. This will extend the SAHR canister shaft and relieve the tension on the parking brake cable.
While using a 15 mm wrench to hold the SAHR canister shaft, loosen the jam nut on the threaded rod with a 16 mm wrench.
While using the 15 mm wrench to hold the canister shaft, unscrew the threaded rod using an 8 mm wrench. The rod must be unscrewed approximately 2.5 inches before the cable disconnects.
Turn the key to OFF.

figure.caption: Figure 42. Park Brake Cable Connection to SAHR Canister

step1.para: Verify that the key is OFF, and place the transmission in either the P, PB or N position.
Remove the two 30 Amp fuses that provide power to the brake system motors. They are in the fuse panel located on the engine side of the cowl. Refer to FIGURE 37 .
Connect the EZ-TECH ® to the diagnostic connector located under the center of the instrument panel. Refer to FIGURE 38 . Set the ignition key to ON, start the EZ-TECH ® and open the TOOLBOX™ program.
Verify that the brake fluid level in the MC reservoir is at the MAX mark.
Depressurize the system as follows:

step2.para: Depress the brake pedal a minimum of 30 times.
Use the EZ-TECH ® and TOOLBOX™ to verify that pressure at both accumulators is at 0 psi.

warning.para: Batteries expel explosive gases. Keep sparks, flames, burning cigarettes, or other ignition sources away at all times. Always wear safety glasses and a face shield when working near batteries to prevent personal injury.

step1.para: Set the ignition key to OFF and disconnect the battery negative cable (including the ECM ground cable).
Prepare the pressure bleeder according to the instructions provided with the equipment.

item.para: If a fluid bleeder system is used, fill the pressure bleeder with new specified brake fluid from a sealed container.

If an air bleeder system is used, the fluid level in the MC reservoir must be monitored to ensure that the level never drops below the MIN mark during the bleed procedure. A typical air-over-fluid bleeder setup is shown in FIGURE 39.

step1.para: Install the service tool adapter (ZTSE4678) between the bleed equipment and the MC reservoir filler neck. Ensure that the adapter is securely tightened onto the MC reservoir filler neck.
Apply 2.4 bar (35 PSI) pressure on the MC reservoir with the bleeding equipment.

Fit bleeder hose onto the bleeder screw on the SAHR canister manifold. Refer to FIGURE 43. Submerge free end of bleeder hose into the bleed bottle. (Note the fluid level in the bottle before starting.)

Open the bleeder screw until the fluid begins to flow (about 3/4 turn). After draining 250 cc (8.5 oz) of fluid, check the stream for air bubbles. When no further air bubbles enter the bleed bottle, close the bleeder screw.
Remove the bleeder hose and torque the bleeder screw to 12 to 16 Nm (8.6 to 11.5 Lbf-ft).

figure.caption: Figure 43. Location of SAHR Bleeder Screw

step1.para: Connect the battery and install the two pump motor fuses.
Switch ON the ignition. HCU pump motors will start up automatically and fill the accumulators (running time approximately 45 seconds).*

Using the EZ-TECH ® and the TOOLBOX™ program, select the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function from the EOL pull down menu. This function helps clear air from the system by depressurizing and repressurizing both accumulators. A dialog box will indicate when the function is complete.
Release pressure from the MC reservoir via the bleed equipment. Disconnect bleed equipment from MC reservoir filler neck and install the MC reservoir cap.
Using the EZ-TECH ® and the TOOLBOX™ program, deplete the accumulators again by selecting the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function from the EOL pull down menu.
When the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function has completed, fill (or drain) the MC reservoir to the MAX mark. Use new DOT 3 or DOT 4 brake fluid from a sealed container if filling.
Verify that the MC reservoir cap is installed.

caution.para: Before installing a parking brake cable, inspect the cable strands where visible. If the strands are damaged or starting to unwind, replace the cable.
While installing a parking brake cable, only the threaded rod should rotate. Do not allow the cable to twist during installation.

step1.para: Connect the parking brake cable to the SAHR canister as follows:

item.para: Place the transmission in neutral (N), not Park (P or PB), and turn the key ON.

While pressing the brake pedal, press the dash mounted PARK BRAKE switch to release the parking brake. This should extend the SAHR canister shaft to allow easier connection of the parking brake cable.
If the SAHR shaft is extended, proceed to step 21E.
If the SAHR shaft is NOT extended, proceed to the following step.
Connect the EZ-TECH ® to the diagnostic connector and open the TOOLBOX™ program.
Use TOOLBOX to release the parking brake (use the 'Component Tests' menu). Releasing the parking brake pressurizes the SAHR canister and extends the canister shaft.

Lubricate the threaded rod end of the parking brake cable by placing a small amount of grease at the point where the threaded rod contacts the 'ball' at the end of the inner cable ( FIGURE 44). This will prevent the inner cable from twisting when the threaded rod is turned.

Screw the threaded rod end of the cable into the SAHR canister shaft. While using a 15 mm wrench to hold the shaft, use an 8 mm wrench to continue threading the rod into the shaft until the 'hash' mark on the threaded rod is flush with the end of the shaft. Refer to FIGURE 42.
While using the 15 mm wrench to hold the SAHR canister shaft, use a 16 mm wrench to tighten the threaded rod jam nut against the end of the shaft.

step1.para: Set the transmission to either the P or PB position (if available) and turn the key OFF. Verify that the parking brake applies.
If you were referred to this procedure from an installation procedure, return to the original procedure now; otherwise, proceed to the next step.

Set the ignition key to ON. Using the EZ-TECH ® and the TOOLBOX™ program clear all brake system related inactive fault codes. (Codes may have been set while disconnecting and reconnecting power to the system.) If active fault codes are indicated, refer to Section 5, DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING
to make the necessary repairs .
Set the ignition key to OFF and disconnect the EZ-TECH ® from the diagnostic connector.
Remove the wheel chocks.

svcsubproc.para: * If HCU pump motors fail to deliver a sufficient amount of fluid, the ECU-Module will control the HCU pump motors in a self priming procedure. HCU pump motors should stop within 3 minutes, with brake warning light and buzzer OFF. If that is not the case (one or both pumps do not prime), performing the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function in the following steps should correct the problem. After completing the DEPLETE ACCUMULATORS function, both accumulators should be fully charged as indicated on the TOOLBOX™ screen. If an accumulator is still not charging correctly refer to Section 5, DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING to make the necessary repairs.

figure.caption: Figure 44. Parking Brake Cable Lubrication Point

calloutgroup.callout1: 4. LUBRICATE ON THIS SIDE OF CABLE END BALL
